body:
It's worth documenting which OS was installed on your GCE instance.

On Tue, Mar 1, 2016 at 2:24 PM Stanley Cheung notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I tried following the Python installation steps:
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/master/src/python/grpcio#from-pypi and
> got this error
> 
> ```
> Installed /tmp/pip-build-3yV22j/grpcio/.eggs/protobuf-3.0.0b2-py2.7.egg
> Searching for futures>=2.2.0
> Reading https://pypi.python.org/simple/futures/
> Best match: futures 3.0.5
> Downloading https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/f/futures/futures-3.0.5.tar.gz#md5=ced2c365e518242512d7a398b515ff95
> Processing futures-3.0.5.tar.gz
> Writing /tmp/easy_install-tByYlQ/futures-3.0.5/setup.cfg
> Running futures-3.0.5/setup.py -q bdist_egg --dist-dir /tmp/easy_install-tByYlQ/futures-3.0.5/egg-dist-tmp-9KUkrJ
> creating /tmp/pip-build-3yV22j/grpcio/.eggs/futures-3.0.5-py2.7.egg
> Extracting futures-3.0.5-py2.7.egg to /tmp/pip-build-3yV22j/grpcio/.eggs
> 
> Installed /tmp/pip-build-3yV22j/grpcio/.eggs/futures-3.0.5-py2.7.egg
> Searching for enum34>=1.0.4
> Reading https://pypi.python.org/simple/enum34/
> Best match: enum34 1.1.2
> Downloading https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/e/enum34/enum34-1.1.2.zip#md5=a9ebbad4ce451c1298cf094de07cdf69
> Processing enum34-1.1.2.zip
> Writing /tmp/easy_install-Jo2a8p/enum34-1.1.2/setup.cfg
> Running enum34-1.1.2/setup.py -q bdist_egg --dist-dir /tmp/easy_install-Jo2a8p/enum34-1.1.2/egg-dist-tmp-zDwsrA
> zip_safe flag not set; analyzing archive contents...
> Moving enum34-1.1.2-py2.7.egg to /tmp/pip-build-3yV22j/grpcio/.eggs
> 
> Installed /tmp/pip-build-3yV22j/grpcio/.eggs/enum34-1.1.2-py2.7.egg
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
>   File "/tmp/pip-build-3yV22j/grpcio/setup.py", line 242, in <module>
>     setuptools.setup(**setup_arguments)
>   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/core.py", line 111, in setup
>     _setup_distribution = dist = klass(attrs)
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/setuptools/dist.py", line 269, in __init__
>     self.fetch_build_eggs(attrs['setup_requires'])
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/setuptools/dist.py", line 313, in fetch_build_eggs
>     replace_conflicting=True,
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 827, in resolve
>     dist = best[req.key] = env.best_match(req, ws, installer)
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 1065, in best_match
>     dist = working_set.find(req)
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 702, in find
>     raise VersionConflict(dist, req)
> pkg_resources.VersionConflict: (six 1.8.0 (/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages), Requirement.parse('six>=1.10'))
> 
> ----------------------------------------
> ```
> 
> Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-build-3yV22j/grpcio
> 
> I was in a fresh GCE instance. I tried a few things I found from searching
> for the error on google (e.g. make sure setuptools, pip, etc are up to
> date) but the error still happens.
> 
> I am probably missing some pre-requisites, so perhaps it might make sense
> to document those before the installation steps?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/5518.

You can only get that error if a dependency is _already_ installed **and** is owned by the system. There's no way that was a fresh OS w/o Python installed at first (or maybe that's just how Debian is distributed [with batteries included], I'm not sure). The fix is to invoke installation of the dependencies like so:

`pip install --ignore-installed six`

... I imagine y'all want some sort of a 'troubleshooting' section added to the installation docs? I'm beginning to find this surprisingly common...

This fixes the issue for me.

About how to document this, I am not sure. On one hand this seems like an environment issue that is usually fixed by googling, but the solution here doesn't look intuitive and obvious to me.

I think a 'troubleshooting' section will be useful for this type of issue. Do you mind starting such section for Python?
